name: Hello World
desc:
"CodersHub is a programming judge that helps you improve your coding skill. Thanks to Judge0 API, it supports over 20 languages such as c, c++, python, java blah blah blah. You can register for free by click here and just fill username password and email. Sounds easy, isn't it? It's also open source project on Github. Feel free to contribute!"

Welcome to CodersHub!

This problem is an easy one: given integer a and b, calculate a+b.

Input
The first line of input contains two integers, \(a\) and \(b\) \((|a|, |b| \leqslant 10^9)\)

Output
One integer — the result of a+b.

Example

Input
1 2
Output
3
Input
13 37
Output
50

name: Life, Universe and Everything
desc:
Your program is to use the brute-force approach in order to find the Answer to Life, the Universe, and Everything.
 More precisely... rewrite small numbers from input to output. Stop
processing input after reading in the number 42. All numbers at input
are integers of one or two digits.


Example

Input
1
2
88
42
9
Output
1
2
88

name: The Math Problem
desc:
Iyer is not able to give time to his girlfriend so his girlfriend is frustrated. Hence his girlfriend has given him an ultimatum. But Iyer has a problem to solve, so he has given you the problem so that he can spend time with his girlfriend.

Let’s define a function f such that,

f(x,y) = f(y, x) =

= 2*f(x/2, y/2) if x is even and y is even

    = f(x/2, y) if x is even and y is odd

    = f(x, y/2) if x is odd and y is even

    = f(|x-y|/2, min(x,y)) if x is odd and y is odd and min(x,y) is minimum of x and y

Also,
f(0,x) = x

Now, for any given integers m,n, there exists an integer a,b such that a*m + b*n = f(m,n)
Help Iyer find the value of a, b.

Input

First line of input contains an integer t, i.e. no of test cases

Next t lines contains two space separated integers, m,n

Output

Print t lines containing 3 space separated integers, a, b, f(m,n).

Example

Input
2
2 3
1 1
Output
-1 1 1
1 0 1

name: Maze of Martyrs
desc:
There’s a player who has to destroy a maze.


The maze consists of m rows and n columns of which some squares are filled with bricks (denoted by ‘x’) and the rest are empty (denoted by ‘.’). The player can walk only on those squares which are not filled with bricks. There’s a specific square which is not filled with bricks which contains the exit. The player starts from a specific position in the maze. He has to drop bombs at the square he’s standing as he goes from one square to another as he goes from the starting square to the square which contains the exit. So the player can’t step on the same square again as he’s moving.


The player can move in 4 possible directions, if the player is at the square (i,j) then he can go to either of 4 possible squares: (i+1,j), (i-1,j), (i,j+1), (i,j-1), assuming there exists a empty square at that position.


Find the number of possible paths the player can choose to reach the exit.

Input

First line consists of 2 integers, m, n which denotes the row size and column size of the maze respectively.
Next line consists of 4 integers, startX, startY, endX, endY, denoting the row index and column index of the starting square and row index and column index of the ending square respectively.
Next m lines consists of a string of length n denoting the maze at ith row for ith line.

Constraints

  • 1 <= m,n <= 50
  • The maze string consists of either '.' or 'x'
  • 1 <= startX, endX <= n
  • 1 <= startY, endY <= m
  • Starting point and ending point are distinct.

Output

The output should be a single integer, denoting the total number of possible paths.

Example

Input
4 4
1 3 2 4
...x
....
.x.x
Output
5
